subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] RP pronunciation of "moor"
msgSnippet: ... In Reid s day, either Ooze or Foot would have done: these vowels have never been distinguished before /r/.  More recent types of RP use Awe, just like
messageBody:
peter_r_guinness scripsit:
> How is "moor" pronounced in RP? The reason I ask is that I've just
> noticed that on page 13 of the QS manual in the list of examples for
> connecting vowels spells "moor" with an Ooze. I would have thought
> that in RP it would be spelt with a Foot instead. (For me in
> Australian it is spelt with an Awe).

In Reid's day, either Ooze or Foot would have done: these vowels have
never been distinguished before /r/. More recent types of RP use Awe,
just like Australian, so that "moor" and "more" sound the same.

Some American accents likewise make no distinction, but the more usual
case is Ooze.

--
Verbogeny is one of the pleasurettes John Cowan <cowan@...>
of a creatific thinkerizer. http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
--Peter da Silva

peter_r_guinness scripsit:
> How is "moor" pronounced in RP?  The reason I ask is that I've just 
> noticed that on page 13 of the QS manual in the list of examples for 
> connecting vowels spells "moor" with an Ooze.  I would have thought 
> that in RP it would be spelt with a Foot instead.  (For me in 
> Australian it is spelt with an Awe).

In Reid's day, either Ooze or Foot would have done: these vowels have
never been distinguished before /r/.  More recent types of RP use Awe,
just like Australian, so that "moor" and "more" sound the same.

Some American accents likewise make no distinction, but the more usual
case is Ooze.
